awd_titl_txt: Institutional Transformation: Empowering Faculty to Cultivate a Culture of Ethics in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Most scientific ethics training programs rely heavily on online or in-person training, but such programs are limited in their efficacy and often fail to address the broader cultural aspects of scientific ethics and scientific misconduct. The goal of this project is to cultivate a culture of scientific ethics at the UC San Diego Jacobs School of Engineering. The investigators will do so by using a diversity of approaches at multiple levels within the school. A major component will be to empower faculty and other stakeholders to create a self-perpetuating culture of scientific ethics at their institution. Social surveys will be used to assess and understand the current ethical culture at UC San Diego. Next, the investigators will organize a retreat with deans, faculty, and administrators to discuss scientific ethics and hold a workshop based on findings from conversations at the retreat. The workshop will also be used to conduct a comprehensive literature review on pathways for creating a culture of scientific ethics, and to develop specific plans for doing so at UC San Diego. The final research component will be systematically testing and evaluating the impact of their activities on scientific ethics at their university.

The main goal of this study is to understand how to create a culture of scientific ethics at a major university and to then use that information to create institutional transformation at UC San Diego. The project moves beyond current approaches to studying and encouraging scientific ethics in four ways: (1) comparing faculty perceptions to gauge the presence of an ethical culture; (2) empowering faculty as agents of cultural change; (3) applying department specific approaches to encouraging and cultivating a culture of ethics; and (4) emphasizing the importance of local cultures and climates for shaping ethical behavior, rather than simply explaining it as the behavior of one or two unethical individuals. These four novel elements will advance understanding of research integrity and provide tools for affecting cultural changes towards ethical science at major research universities. Overall, the project will benefit society by promoting ethical teaching, training, and learning, and by nurturing a community of researchers who will be better prepared to engage in discussions about ethical dimensions of academia and research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project, "Institutional Transformation: Empowering Faculty to Cultivate a Culture of Ethics in Engineering," aimed to cultivate a culture of ethics at the Jacobs School of Engineering at the University of California, San Diego. Typically, ethics education in graduate engineering tends to be confined to a classroom experience or formal training. While this may have value, studies have shown the impact is much less than what is absorbed in the research environment. We sought instead to foster an institutional culture of ethics, built on discussions among faculty, research staff, and trainees. We endeavored to identify ways to empower and support faculty in fostering formal and informal conversations at multiple levels of the institution.

At the start of the project, we conducted five focus groups with faculty and trainees at JSOE. The findings from these focus groups helped us to characterize the ethical culture at JSOE and identify needs and attitudes surrounding ethics education. Based on the focus group discussions, we created a survey meant to identify perceptions of behaviors related to ethical culture. This baseline assessment was the starting point for the stakeholder retreat and serves as a snapshot of the climate at JSOE at the start of the project.

We held a stakeholder retreat for JSOE faculty and students and experts in ethics education to develop strategies for starting conversations about ethics topics. Retreat participants identified as a major need guidance on rules and best practices regarding responsible conduct of research, mentorship, authorship, and data management. In response, we convened working groups with JSOE faculty and staff to draft guideline documents. These guideline documents can be found on the JSOE website. We also compiled a list of suggestions for activities that faculty and students could organize both in the classroom and within research groups. These resources are available on the JSOE website.

We took a qualitative approach to evaluation, hoping to discern subtleties that would not be measurable with quantitative methods. The summative evaluation in the final months of the project mirrored the baseline assessment. We conducted five more focus groups and sent out the same survey. We convened a panel of external evaluators to review and compare the formative and summative evaluations. Detecting change and attributing it to our efforts would have been difficult under normal circumstances, but this assessment was also confounded by the COVID-19 pandemic which greatly decreased opportunities for the informal conversations that were the target of this project.

There was remarkable consistency overall between the formative and summative evaluations, both in the focus group data and the survey findings. This suggests little change over the project period but also underscores the persistent importance of honesty, rigor, and social responsibility to the JSOE community; the centrality of mentorship and relationships in reinforcing these values; and the opportunities for the institution to lead by supporting strong and trusting relationships among faculty and students. Survey results were suggestive, but not conclusive.

Nonetheless, the increasing commitment to ethics on the part of the Jacobs School of Engineering (JSOE) leadership is evident in the support of this project, the recruitment of a faculty member as the inaugural director for JSOE research ethics, the formation of an ethics curriculum committee, insertion of ethics as a primary objective for graduate and undergraduate education strategic planning, and the support of experimental ethics modules in undergraduate courses. Interest in improving ethics education at JSOE is also reflected in the participation of many faculty in the activities associated with this project.

We have learned through both the project and its evaluation that supporting a culture of ethics at JSOE - or in any institution of higher education - depends on trusting interpersonal relationships, especially between faculty and their advisees. Relationships must encourage discussion, be free of persecution and exploitation, and prioritize dignity in the face of the substantive pressures in academic life. Equally, the institution plays a key role scaffolding the ethical culture with procedures and rules, particularly for well-understood ethical concerns like sexual harassment. The outcomes from this project will advance knowledge by providing examples for future initiatives in ethics education. Our approach to assessment can also offer lessons for future projects that seek to evaluate the subtleties of cultural change. The broader impact of this work will unfold as future initiatives at the JSOE raise awareness of the resources we have developed and encourage the faculty and students to engage in conversations about ethics. The conversations begun through this project are continuing both inside the JSOE and within the community of educators committed to ethics in undergraduate and graduate education. We anticipate that these conversations will help align expectations for responsible conduct in research and inspire the next generation of engineers to consider the impact of their work.
